news_summary: Advancements in health research reveal innovative healing materials, simple lifestyle changes that extend lifespan, breakthroughs in understanding IBS-D, and AI-designed treatments for COVID-19.
news_summary_fr: Les progrès de la recherche en matière de santé révèlent des matériaux de guérison innovants, des changements de mode de vie simples qui prolongent la durée de vie, des avancées dans la compréhension du syndrome de l'intestin irritable et des traitements conçus par l'IA pour le COVID-19.
news_summary_es: Los avances en la investigación sanitaria revelan materiales curativos innovadores, sencillos cambios en el estilo de vida que prolongan la esperanza de vida, avances en la comprensión del SII-D y tratamientos diseñados por la IA para la COVID-19.

articles.title: Columbia scientists turn yogurt into a healing gel that mimics human tissue
articles.summary: Scientists at Columbia Engineering have developed an injectable hydrogel made from yogurt-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) that could revolutionize regenerative medicine. These EVs serve both as healing agents and as structural components, eliminating the need for added chemicals. The innovation leverages everyday dairy products like yogurt to create a biocompatible material that mimics natural tissue and enhances healing.
articles.content:
Researchers from Columbia Engineering have established a framework for the design of bioactive injectable hydrogels formulated with extracellular vesicles (EVs) for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine applications.

Published on July 25 in Matter, Santiago Correa, assistant professor of biomedical engineering at Columbia Engineering, and his collaborators describe an injectable hydrogel platform that uses EVs from milk to address longstanding barriers in the development of biomaterials for regenerative medicine. EVs are particles naturally secreted by cells and carry hundreds of biological signals, like proteins and genetic material, enabling sophisticated cellular communication that synthetic materials cannot easily replicate.

In this study, Correa and colleagues designed a hydrogel system where EVs play a dual role: they act as bioactive cargo but also serve as essential structural building blocks, by crosslinking biocompatible polymers to form an injectable material. Using an unconventional approach that leveraged milk EVs from yogurt, the team was able to overcome yield constraints that hinder the development of EV-based biomaterials. The yogurt EVs enabled the hydrogel to both mimic the mechanics of living tissue and actively engage surrounding cells, promoting healing and tissue regeneration without the need for additional chemical additives.

"This project started as a basic question about how to build EV-based hydrogels. Yogurt EVs gave us a practical tool for that, but they turned out to be more than a model," said Correa who led the study with Artemis Margaronis, an NSF graduate research fellow in the Correa lab. "We found that they have inherent regenerative potential, which opens the door to new, accessible therapeutic materials."

Correa directs the Nanoscale Immunoengineering Lab at Columbia University, where his research focuses on drug delivery and immunoengineering. He is also a member of the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center and collaborated on this project with Kam Leong, a fellow Columbia Engineering faculty member. The study was further strengthened through international collaboration with researchers from the University of Padova, including Elisa Cimetta (Department of Industrial Engineering) and graduate student Caterina Piunti. By combining Padova team's expertise in agricultural EV sourcing with the Correa lab's experience in nanomaterials and polymer-based hydrogels, the team demonstrated the power of cross-disciplinary, global partnerships in advancing biomaterials innovation.

By using yogurt-derived EVs, the team defined a design space for generating hydrogels that incorporate EVs as both structural and biological elements. They further validated the approach using EVs derived from mammalian cells and bacteria, demonstrating that the platform is modular and compatible with diverse vesicle sources. This could open the door to advanced applications in wound healing and regenerative medicine, where current treatments often fall short in promoting long-term tissue repair. By integrating EVs directly into the hydrogel structure, the material enables sustained delivery of their bioactive signals. Because the hydrogel is injectable, it can also be delivered locally to damaged tissue.

Early experiments show that yogurt EV hydrogels are biocompatible and drive potent angiogenic activity within one week in immunocompetent mice, demonstrating that agricultural EVs not only enable fundamental biomaterials research but also hold therapeutic potential as a next-generation biotechnology. In mice, the material showed no signs of adverse reaction and instead promoted the formation of new blood vessels, a key step in effective tissue regeneration. Correa's team also observed that the hydrogel creates a unique immune environment enriched in anti-inflammatory cell types, which may contribute to the observed tissue repair processes. The team is now exploring how this immune response could help guide tissue regeneration.

"Being able to design a material that closely mimics the body's natural environment while also speed up the healing process opens a new world of possibilities for regenerative medicine," said Margaronis. "Moments like these remind me why the research field in biomedical engineering is always on the cusp of something exciting."
articles.reasoning: This article describes a scientific breakthrough in regenerative medicine using a novel, biocompatible hydrogel derived from yogurt, which has potential to improve healing and tissue regeneration. It represents a positive medical advance that could benefit many people.
articles.personality_title: Scientists create healing gel from yogurt that mimics human tissue
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists at Columbia Engineering have been exploring new ways to help the body heal itself using materials that work like natural tissue. They focused on extracellular vesicles (EVs), tiny particles found in milk and yogurt, which can carry important signals to support cell repair.

**What happened**
The researchers developed an injectable gel made from EVs derived from yogurt. This gel acts both as a healing agent and a scaffold, meaning it helps damaged tissue regrow while also supporting the structure of new cells. Unlike other gels, it doesn't need extra chemicals to work, making it safer and more natural.

**Impact**
This innovative gel could change regenerative medicine by offering a more natural way to repair damaged tissues. It uses everyday dairy products, making it potentially easier and cheaper to produce. Most importantly, it supports better healing, which could help people recover faster from injuries or surgeries.

**What's next step**
The team will continue testing the gel in different medical scenarios to understand how well it works in the body. They aim to refine the gel for use in clinics, bringing this promising treatment closer to patients.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A healing gel made from yogurt-derived particles offers a natural, safe way to help the body repair itself and may soon improve recovery from injuries and surgeries.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques créent un gel guérisseur à base de yaourt qui imite les tissus humains
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Des scientifiques de Columbia Engineering cherchent de nouvelles façons d'aider le corps à se réparer en utilisant des matériaux qui fonctionnent comme les tissus naturels. Ils se sont intéressés aux vésicules extracellulaires (VE), de minuscules particules présentes dans le lait et le yaourt, qui transportent des signaux importants pour soutenir la réparation cellulaire.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Les chercheurs ont développé un gel injectable fabriqué à partir de VE dérivées du yaourt. Ce gel agit à la fois comme agent de guérison et comme support, aidant les tissus endommagés à repousser tout en soutenant la structure des nouvelles cellules. Contrairement à d'autres gels, il ne nécessite pas de produits chimiques supplémentaires, ce qui le rend plus sûr et plus naturel.

**Impact**
Ce gel innovant pourrait transformer la médecine régénérative en offrant une méthode plus naturelle pour réparer les tissus endommagés. Il utilise des produits laitiers courants, ce qui pourrait faciliter et réduire le coût de sa production. Surtout, il favorise une meilleure guérison, aidant les patients à récupérer plus rapidement après des blessures ou des opérations.

**Prochaine étape**
L'équipe continuera à tester le gel dans différents contextes médicaux pour mieux comprendre son efficacité dans le corps. Ils veulent améliorer ce gel pour qu'il soit utilisé en clinique, rapprochant ainsi ce traitement prometteur des patients.

**Une phrase clé**
Un gel guérisseur à base de particules dérivées du yaourt offre une méthode naturelle et sûre pour aider le corps à se réparer et pourrait bientôt améliorer la récupération après blessures et opérations.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos crean un gel curativo a partir de yogur que imita el tejido humano
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Científicos de Columbia Engineering han explorado nuevas formas de ayudar al cuerpo a sanarse usando materiales que funcionan como el tejido natural. Se centraron en vesículas extracelulares (VE), pequeñas partículas presentes en la leche y el yogur que pueden llevar señales importantes para apoyar la reparación celular.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores desarrollaron un gel inyectable hecho de VE derivadas del yogur. Este gel actúa tanto como agente curativo como soporte, ayudando a que el tejido dañado vuelva a crecer mientras sostiene la estructura de las nuevas células. A diferencia de otros geles, no necesita químicos adicionales, haciéndolo más seguro y natural.

**Impacto**
Este innovador gel podría cambiar la medicina regenerativa al ofrecer una forma más natural de reparar tejidos dañados. Usa productos lácteos comunes, lo que podría facilitar y abaratar su producción. Lo más importante es que favorece una mejor recuperación, ayudando a las personas a sanar más rápido tras lesiones o cirugías.

**Próximo paso**
El equipo seguirá probando el gel en distintos escenarios médicos para entender qué tan bien funciona dentro del cuerpo. Buscan perfeccionar el gel para su uso en clínicas, acercando este prometedor tratamiento a los pacientes.

**Una frase clave**
Un gel curativo hecho con partículas derivadas del yogur ofrece una forma natural y segura de ayudar al cuerpo a repararse y pronto podría mejorar la recuperación tras lesiones y cirugías.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a gentle swirl of creamy yogurt transforming into a translucent, soft gel-like network resembling human tissue fibers, with tiny glowing vesicle particles embedded within the gel, surrounded by softly glowing cellular shapes and delicate blood vessel patterns forming in the background, all rendered in natural pastel tones of white, cream, soft pinks, and gentle greens.

articles.title: Walk faster, live longer: How just 15 minutes a day can boost lifespan
articles.summary: Fast walking, even just 15 minutes a day, can dramatically reduce the risk of death, especially from heart disease, according to a large study involving nearly 80,000 low-income and predominantly Black Americans in the South. The findings not only affirm the well-known health benefits of walking but also highlight how pace matters and how fast walking offers a powerful, accessible tool for improving health across underserved communities.
articles.content:
Regular walking is widely recognized for its significant benefits to overall health and well-being. Previous research has primarily focused on middle-to-high-income White populations. Now, a novel analysis using data from the Southern Community Cohort Study, involving 79,856 predominantly low-income and Black individuals across 12 southeastern US states, confirms the benefits of regular walking, especially at a faster pace, within a crucial, underrepresented group. The new study appearing in the American Journal of Preventive Medicine, published by Elsevier, underscores the importance of promoting walking, particularly at a brisk pace, as an effective form of physical activity for improving health.

Lead investigator Wei Zheng, MD, PhD, Division of Epidemiology, Department of Medicine, Vanderbilt Epidemiology Center, School of Medicine, Vanderbilt University, and Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, says, "While the health benefits of daily walking are well-established, limited research has investigated effects of factors such as walking pace on mortality, particularly in low-income and Black/African-American populations. Our research has shown that fast walking as little as 15 minutes a day was associated with a nearly 20% reduction in total mortality, while a smaller reduction in mortality was found in association with more than three hours of daily slow walking. This benefit remained strong even after accounting for other lifestyle factors and was consistent across various sensitivity analyses."

Participants reported the average amount of time per day (minutes) they typically spend "walking slowly (such as moving around, walking at work, walking the dog, or engaging in light exercise)" and "walking fast (such as climbing stairs, brisk walking, or exercising)." Information regarding vital status and cause of death was obtained by linking the cohort to the National Death Index.

The protective effect of fast walking extended to all causes of death but was most pronounced for cardiovascular diseases. Importantly, the benefits of fast walking were independent of overall leisure-time physical activity levels (LTPA). Even for those who are already engaged in slow walking or some LTPA, adding more fast walking further reduced mortality.

According to the study the benefits of fast walking related to cardiovascular health are:

Boosts heart efficiency: As an aerobic exercise, fast walking improves cardiac output, increases oxygen delivery, and enhances the efficiency of the heart's pumping action, leading to better overall cardiovascular health.

Manages cardiovascular risk factors: Regular fast walking helps control body weight and composition, reducing obesity and related risks like hypertension and dyslipidemia.

Highly accessible: Fast walking is a convenient, low-impact activity suitable for individuals of all ages and fitness levels.

Low-income populations often face economic constraints and are more likely to reside in impoverished, highly polluted communities with limited access to safe walking spaces. Additionally, these populations tend to have a higher prevalence of lifestyle behaviors that may increase disease risk and mortality, such as lower quality diet, cigarette smoking, and heavy alcohol consumption. At the same time, there are other challenges for individuals with low income such as lack of access to health insurance or healthcare that may also increase mortality. These factors collectively contribute to an increased mortality among low-income individuals and may potentially elucidate the racial disparities observed in longevity. By demonstrating the benefits of fast walking in this study, this research provides direct evidence to inform targeted interventions and policies to improve health equity.

Lead author of the article Lili Liu, MPH, Division of Epidemiology, Department of Medicine, Vanderbilt Epidemiology Center, School of Medicine, and Vanderbilt University, Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, concludes, "Public health campaigns and community-based programs can emphasize the importance and availability of fast walking to improve health outcomes, providing resources and support to facilitate increased fast walking within all communities. Furthermore, the findings of the reduced mortality associated with fast walking pace were supported by previous studies conducted in middle- and upper-middle-income populations. Individuals should strive to incorporate more intense physical activity into their routines, such as brisk walking or other forms of aerobic exercise."
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a simple, accessible way to improve health and longevity, especially benefiting underserved communities. It affirms the positive impact of fast walking on reducing mortality risk, which is encouraging and empowering for a wide audience.
articles.personality_title: Walk faster, live longer: How just 15 minutes a day can boost lifespan
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Walking is a simple and popular way to stay healthy, but most studies focus on wealthier, mostly White groups. This new research looked at nearly 80,000 low-income Black Americans in the southern U.S., a group often overlooked in health studies.

**What happened**
Researchers found that walking faster, even for just 15 minutes a day, significantly lowers the risk of death, especially from heart disease. This study shows that the speed of walking really matters for health, not just the amount.

**Impact**
This discovery offers a powerful and easy tool for improving health and longevity, especially in underserved communities. It means a small daily change—walking a little faster—can make a big difference in living longer and healthier.

**What's next step**
The next step is to share these findings widely to encourage more people, especially in underserved areas, to add faster walking to their daily routines. Public health programs could focus on promoting quick walks as a simple, accessible way to boost heart health.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Just 15 minutes of faster walking each day can dramatically lower the risk of early death, offering a simple, powerful way to live longer and healthier.
articles.personality_title_fr: Marchez plus vite, vivez plus longtemps : comment seulement 15 minutes par jour peuvent augmenter l'espérance de vie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La marche est une activité simple et populaire pour rester en bonne santé, mais la plupart des études concernent des groupes plus riches et majoritairement blancs. Cette nouvelle recherche a étudié près de 80 000 Afro-Américains à faible revenu dans le sud des États-Unis, un groupe souvent négligé dans les études de santé.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Les chercheurs ont découvert que marcher plus vite, même seulement 15 minutes par jour, réduit significativement le risque de décès, surtout par maladie cardiaque. Cette étude montre que la vitesse de la marche est importante pour la santé, pas seulement la quantité.

**Impact**
Cette découverte offre un moyen simple et puissant d'améliorer la santé et la longévité, surtout dans les communautés défavorisées. Cela signifie qu’un petit changement quotidien—marcher un peu plus vite—peut vraiment aider à vivre plus longtemps et en meilleure santé.

**Prochaine étape**
L'étape suivante est de diffuser largement ces résultats pour encourager plus de personnes, surtout dans les zones défavorisées, à intégrer la marche rapide dans leur routine quotidienne. Les programmes de santé publique pourraient promouvoir la marche rapide comme une méthode simple et accessible pour améliorer la santé cardiaque.

**Une phrase à retenir**
15 minutes de marche rapide chaque jour peuvent réduire considérablement le risque de décès prématuré, offrant un moyen simple et efficace de vivre plus longtemps et en meilleure santé.
articles.personality_title_es: Camina más rápido, vive más tiempo: cómo solo 15 minutos al día pueden aumentar la esperanza de vida
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Caminar es una forma sencilla y popular de mantenerse saludable, pero la mayoría de los estudios se centran en grupos más ricos y mayormente blancos. Esta nueva investigación analizó a casi 80,000 afroamericanos de bajos ingresos en el sur de los EE. UU., un grupo a menudo ignorado en estudios de salud.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores encontraron que caminar más rápido, incluso solo 15 minutos al día, reduce significativamente el riesgo de muerte, especialmente por enfermedades del corazón. Este estudio muestra que la velocidad al caminar realmente importa para la salud, no solo la cantidad.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo ofrece una herramienta poderosa y fácil para mejorar la salud y la longevidad, especialmente en comunidades desatendidas. Significa que un pequeño cambio diario—caminar un poco más rápido—puede marcar una gran diferencia para vivir más y mejor.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente paso es compartir estos resultados ampliamente para animar a más personas, especialmente en áreas desatendidas, a incorporar la caminata rápida en su rutina diaria. Los programas de salud pública podrían enfocarse en promover caminatas rápidas como una forma simple y accesible de mejorar la salud cardíaca.

**Una frase para recordar**
Solo 15 minutos de caminar rápido al día pueden reducir drásticamente el riesgo de muerte prematura, ofreciendo una manera simple y poderosa de vivir más tiempo y con mejor salud.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a vibrant, sunlit community park path winding through a diverse neighborhood, featuring symbolic pairs of walking shoes—some depicted in motion with dynamic, swift brushstrokes to represent brisk walking—alongside subtle heart shapes integrated into the path’s design to symbolize cardiovascular health, all rendered in soft, natural earth tones and gentle greens, evoking vitality, progress, and inclusive well-being.

articles.title: This gut hormone could explain 40% of IBS-D cases—and lead to a cure
articles.summary: A mysterious gut hormone may be behind many cases of chronic diarrhea, especially in people with undiagnosed bile acid malabsorption, a condition often mistaken for irritable bowel syndrome. Researchers from the University of Cambridge identified that the hormone INSL5 spikes when bile acid reaches the colon, triggering intense diarrhea. Their discovery not only sheds light on the biological cause of symptoms but opens the door to a diagnostic blood test and new treatment options, including a surprising existing drug that blocks this hormone’s effects.
articles.content:
High levels of a hormone found in cells in the gut could underlie many cases of chronic diarrhea and help explain up to 40% of cases of patients with irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea, according to a new study led by scientists at the University of Cambridge.

The research, published in the journal Gut, could help in the development of a blood test and points towards a potential new treatment.

When we eat, the liver releases bile acid to break down fats so that they can be absorbed into the body. Bile acid is released into the top end of the small intestine and then absorbed back into the body at the lower end.

However, around one person in every 100 is affected by a condition known as bile acid diarrhea (also known as bile acid malabsorption), whereby the bile acid is not properly re-absorbed and makes its way into the large intestine (colon). It can trigger urgent and watery diarrhea, and patients can risk episodes of incontinence.

Bile acid diarrhea can be difficult to diagnose as there are currently no routine clinical blood tests. Many individuals are given a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), an umbrella term for a range of conditions. As many as one in 20 people is thought to have IBS, of which an estimated one in three patients with diarrhea as their main symptom have undiagnosed bile acid diarrhea.

Studies in mice have previously suggested that the gut hormone known as Insulin-Like Peptide 5 (INSL5) - present in cells at the far end of the colon and rectum - may play a role in chronic diarrhea. INSL5 is released by these cells when irritated by bile acid.

Researchers at the Institute of Metabolic Science, University of Cambridge, have been exploring whether this hormone might also underlie chronic diarrhea in humans. This has been possible thanks to a new antibody test developed by pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly, with whom the team is collaborating, which allows them to measure tiny amounts of INSL5.

A study at the University of Adelaide looking at ways to trigger release of the gut hormone GLP-1 - the hormone upon which weight-loss drugs are based - previously found that giving a bile acid enema to healthy volunteers triggered release of GLP-1, but had the unintended consequence of causing diarrhea. When the Cambridge team analyzed samples from this study, they found that the bile acid enema caused levels of INSL5 to shoot up temporarily - and the higher the INSL5 levels, the faster the volunteers needed to use the toilet. This confirmed that INSL5 is likely to play a role in chronic cases of diarrhea.

When the team analyzed samples obtained from Professor Julian Walters at Imperial College London, which include samples from patients with bile acid diarrhea, they found that while levels of INSL5 were almost undetectable in healthy volunteers, they were much higher in patients with bile acid diarrhea. In addition, the higher the INSL5 level, the more watery their stool samples.

Dr Chris Bannon from the University of Cambridge, the study's first author, said: "This was a very exciting finding because it showed us that this hormone could be playing a big part in symptoms of this misunderstood condition. It also meant it might allow us to develop a blood test to help diagnose bile acid diarrhea if INSL5 levels are only high in these individuals.

"When you go to the doctor with chronic diarrhea, it's likely they'll test for food intolerances, rule out an infection or look for signs of inflammation. There has been significant research interest in the microbiome, but gut hormones have been neglected. But it's becoming increasingly clear that gut hormones play an important role in things like gut health and weight management."

INSL5 also provides a potential target for treatment. Dr Bannon and colleagues obtained further samples from Professor Robin Spiller at the University of Nottingham, who had given the anti-sickness medication ondansetron - known to block the action of INSL5 in mice - to patients with IBS. Analysis of these samples by the Cambridge team showed that around 40% of these patients had raised levels of INSL5, even though they had had bile acid malabsorption ruled out, and these patients responded best to ondansetron.

Exactly why ondansetron is effective is currently unclear, though a known side effect of the drug is constipation. The team will now be investigating this further, hopeful that it will allow them either to repurpose the drug or to develop even better treatments. Bile acid diarrhea is usually treated with so-called bile acid sequestrants, but these are only effective in around two-thirds of patients.

Dr Bannon added: "I often get asked why we would have a hormone that gives you diarrhea. I think of it as a kind of poison sensor. Bile acids aren't meant to be in the colon - they're an irritant to the colon and they're toxic to the microbiome. It makes sense that you would have something that detects toxins and helps the body rid itself of them. But a problem develops if it's always being triggered by bile acid, causing very dramatic symptoms."

Dr Bannon is a clinical fellow in the group led by Professors Fiona Gribble and Frank Reimann at the Institute of Metabolic Science, University of Cambridge.

The research was supported by the Medical Research Council and Wellcome, with additional support from the National Institute for Health and Care Research Cambridge Biomedical Research Centre.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant medical breakthrough identifying a hormone responsible for many cases of chronic diarrhea, which could lead to new diagnostic tests and treatments. This represents hope for patients suffering from IBS-D and related conditions, making it a positive and hopeful development in healthcare.
articles.personality_title: A gut hormone points to new hope for chronic diarrhea sufferers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Many people suffer from chronic diarrhea linked to irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea (IBS-D), but for some, the real cause has remained a mystery. One common culprit, bile acid malabsorption (BAM), often goes undiagnosed and can cause severe digestive issues.

**What happened**
Researchers at the University of Cambridge discovered that a hormone called INSL5, which is released in the gut, spikes when bile acid reaches the colon. This spike triggers intense diarrhea. Their study showed that INSL5 may explain about 40% of IBS-D cases. They also found that a drug already available can block this hormone’s effects, opening the door to new treatments.

**Impact**
This discovery could lead to a simple blood test that detects the hormone, helping doctors identify if BAM is causing a patient’s symptoms. More importantly, it offers a pathway to effective treatments that directly target the hormone, giving relief to many people who have struggled with chronic diarrhea for years.

**What's next step**
The next step is to develop and test the blood diagnostic tool and confirm how well the existing drug works in blocking INSL5 in patients. Researchers will also explore new medications that specifically target this hormone to provide more treatment options.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A newly discovered gut hormone causing chronic diarrhea could soon lead to better diagnosis and treatments, offering hope to millions with IBS-D.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une hormone intestinale ouvre la voie à un nouvel espoir pour les personnes souffrant de diarrhée chronique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Beaucoup de personnes souffrent de diarrhée chronique liée au syndrome de l’intestin irritable avec diarrhée (SII-D), mais pour certains, la cause réelle restait inconnue. Une cause fréquente, la malabsorption des acides biliaires (MAB), est souvent non diagnostiquée et peut provoquer de graves troubles digestifs.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs de l’université de Cambridge ont découvert qu’une hormone appelée INSL5, libérée dans l’intestin, augmente fortement lorsque les acides biliaires atteignent le côlon. Cette augmentation déclenche une diarrhée intense. Leur étude montre que INSL5 pourrait expliquer environ 40 % des cas de SII-D. Ils ont aussi trouvé qu’un médicament déjà disponible peut bloquer les effets de cette hormone, ouvrant la voie à de nouveaux traitements.

**Impact**
Cette découverte pourrait permettre de développer un simple test sanguin pour détecter l’hormone, aidant les médecins à identifier si une MAB cause les symptômes du patient. Surtout, elle offre une voie vers des traitements efficaces ciblant directement l’hormone, apportant un soulagement à de nombreuses personnes qui souffrent de diarrhée chronique depuis des années.

**Prochaine étape**
L’étape suivante est de développer et tester l’outil de diagnostic sanguin et de confirmer l’efficacité du médicament existant pour bloquer INSL5 chez les patients. Les chercheurs vont aussi explorer de nouveaux médicaments visant spécifiquement cette hormone pour offrir plus d’options de traitement.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Une hormone intestinale récemment découverte responsable de la diarrhée chronique pourrait bientôt permettre un meilleur diagnostic et de nouveaux traitements, offrant de l’espoir à des millions de personnes atteintes de SII-D.
articles.personality_title_es: Una hormona intestinal apunta a una nueva esperanza para quienes sufren diarrea crónica
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Muchas personas sufren diarrea crónica relacionada con el síndrome del intestino irritable con diarrea (SII-D), pero para algunos, la causa real ha sido un misterio. Una causa común, la malabsorción de ácidos biliares (MAB), a menudo no se diagnostica y puede causar problemas digestivos graves.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores de la Universidad de Cambridge descubrieron que una hormona llamada INSL5, que se libera en el intestino, aumenta cuando el ácido biliar llega al colon. Este aumento provoca diarrea intensa. Su estudio mostró que INSL5 podría explicar alrededor del 40 % de los casos de SII-D. También encontraron que un medicamento ya existente puede bloquear los efectos de esta hormona, abriendo la puerta a nuevos tratamientos.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento podría llevar a una prueba de sangre simple para detectar la hormona, ayudando a los médicos a identificar si la MAB está causando los síntomas de un paciente. Más importante aún, ofrece un camino hacia tratamientos efectivos que apuntan directamente a la hormona, brindando alivio a muchas personas que han sufrido diarrea crónica durante años.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente paso es desarrollar y probar la herramienta de diagnóstico por sangre y confirmar qué tan bien funciona el medicamento existente para bloquear INSL5 en pacientes. Los investigadores también explorarán nuevos medicamentos que apunten específicamente a esta hormona para ofrecer más opciones de tratamiento.

**Resumen en una frase**
Una hormona intestinal recién descubierta que causa diarrea crónica podría pronto permitir un mejor diagnóstico y tratamientos, ofreciendo esperanza a millones con SII-D.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing, gently coiled intestine made of soft, natural hues, with delicate, luminescent droplets symbolizing the gut hormone INSL5 flowing along the colon’s curve, surrounded by subtle abstract waves of bile acid represented as translucent golden streams, all set against a calm, neutral background that evokes healing and scientific discovery.

articles.title: The Virtual Lab of AI agents designs new SARS-CoV-2 nanobodies
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09442-9The Virtual Lab of AI agents designs new SARS-CoV-2 nanobodies
articles.content: Science frequently benefits from teams of interdisciplinary researchers1–3, but many scientists do not have easy access to experts from multiple fields4,5. While large language models (LLMs) have shown an impressive ability to aid researchers across diverse domains, their uses have been largely limited to answering specific scientific questions rather than performing open-ended research6–11. Here, we expand the capabilities of LLMs for science by introducing the Virtual Lab, an AI-human research collaboration to perform sophisticated, interdisciplinary science research. The Virtual Lab consists of an LLM principal investigator agent guiding a team of LLM scientist agents through a series of research meetings, with a human researcher providing high-level feedback. We apply the Virtual Lab to design nanobody binders to recent variants of SARS-CoV-2. The Virtual Lab creates a novel computational nanobody design pipeline that incorporates ESM, AlphaFold-Multimer, and Rosetta and designs 92 new nanobodies. Experimental validation reveals a range of functional nanobodies with promising binding profiles across SARS-CoV-2 variants. In particular, two new nanobodies exhibit improved binding to the recent JN.1 or KP.3 variants12,13 while maintaining strong binding to the ancestral viral spike protein, suggesting exciting candidates for further investigation. This demonstrates how the Virtual Lab can rapidly make an impactful, real-world scientific discovery.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a scientific breakthrough where AI agents have designed new nanobodies targeting SARS-CoV-2, which is a significant medical advance with potential to improve COVID-19 treatment or prevention, offering hope for better health outcomes.
articles.personality_title: AI-powered virtual lab creates new nanobodies to fight COVID-19
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists often work best when they team up across different fields, but not everyone has easy access to experts outside their area. Recently, advanced AI tools known as large language models (LLMs) have helped researchers by answering questions, but they haven’t been used much for original scientific discovery.

**What happened**
A new virtual lab made up of AI agents has been developed to do open-ended research. This AI-powered system successfully designed new nanobodies, which are tiny, specially engineered antibodies that can target the SARS-CoV-2 virus—the cause of COVID-19.

**Impact**
These newly created nanobodies have the potential to improve treatments or prevention strategies against COVID-19. This breakthrough showcases how AI can accelerate scientific discovery in medicine, offering hope for better health outcomes worldwide.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to continue testing these AI-designed nanobodies in labs and clinical trials to ensure they are safe and effective. They also aim to expand the Virtual Lab approach to tackle other diseases, using AI to speed up innovation.

**One-sentence takeaway**
AI-driven virtual labs are opening new doors in medical research by designing powerful tools like nanobodies to fight viruses like SARS-CoV-2.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un laboratoire virtuel piloté par l’IA crée de nouveaux nanocorps pour lutter contre le COVID-19
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques travaillent souvent mieux en équipe entre différentes disciplines, mais tout le monde n’a pas facilement accès à des experts d’autres domaines. Récemment, des outils avancés d’intelligence artificielle, appelés grands modèles de langage (LLM), ont aidé les chercheurs en répondant à des questions, mais ils n’étaient pas beaucoup utilisés pour faire des découvertes scientifiques originales.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Un nouveau laboratoire virtuel composé d’agents IA a été développé pour mener des recherches ouvertes. Ce système alimenté par l’IA a réussi à créer de nouveaux nanocorps, de petites anticorps spécialement conçues pour cibler le virus SARS-CoV-2, responsable du COVID-19.

**Impact**
Ces nanocorps nouvellement créés pourraient améliorer les traitements ou les stratégies de prévention contre le COVID-19. Cette avancée montre comment l’IA peut accélérer la recherche médicale, offrant de l’espoir pour de meilleurs résultats sanitaires dans le monde.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient de continuer à tester ces nanocorps conçus par l’IA en laboratoire et dans des essais cliniques pour vérifier leur sécurité et leur efficacité. Ils veulent aussi étendre l’approche du laboratoire virtuel à d’autres maladies, en utilisant l’IA pour accélérer l’innovation.

**Un résumé en une phrase**
Les laboratoires virtuels pilotés par l’IA ouvrent de nouvelles voies en recherche médicale en créant des outils puissants comme les nanocorps pour combattre des virus comme le SARS-CoV-2.
articles.personality_title_es: Laboratorio virtual con IA crea nuevos nanocuerpos para combatir el COVID-19
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos suelen trabajar mejor en equipos interdisciplinarios, pero no todos tienen fácil acceso a expertos de otras áreas. Recientemente, herramientas avanzadas de inteligencia artificial llamadas grandes modelos de lenguaje (LLM) han ayudado a los investigadores respondiendo preguntas, pero no se habían usado mucho para hacer descubrimientos científicos originales.

**Qué pasó**
Se desarrolló un nuevo laboratorio virtual formado por agentes de IA para realizar investigaciones abiertas. Este sistema impulsado por IA logró diseñar nuevos nanocuerpos, que son anticuerpos diminutos especialmente diseñados para atacar el virus SARS-CoV-2, causante del COVID-19.

**Impacto**
Estos nuevos nanocuerpos tienen el potencial de mejorar los tratamientos o estrategias de prevención contra el COVID-19. Este avance demuestra cómo la IA puede acelerar el descubrimiento científico en medicina, ofreciendo esperanza para mejores resultados de salud en todo el mundo.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean seguir probando estos nanocuerpos diseñados por IA en laboratorios y ensayos clínicos para asegurar que sean seguros y efectivos. También quieren ampliar el enfoque del laboratorio virtual para atacar otras enfermedades, usando IA para acelerar la innovación.

**Una frase clave**
Los laboratorios virtuales impulsados por IA están abriendo nuevas puertas en la investigación médica al diseñar herramientas poderosas como nanocuerpos para combatir virus como el SARS-CoV-2.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of an abstract virtual laboratory where glowing, interconnected neural network nodes gently form the shapes of nanobody molecules binding to stylized, softly colored virus spike proteins, all surrounded by floating translucent screens displaying elegant computational patterns and molecular structures, rendered in natural blues, greens, and soft earth tones.
